mojo.description:
This goal is used to run Jetty with a pre-assembled war.

It accepts exactly the same options as the run-war goal. However, it doesn't assume that the current artifact is a webapp and doesn't try to assemble it into a war before its execution. So using it makes sense only when used in conjunction with the war configuration parameter pointing to a pre-built WAR.

This goal is useful e.g. for launching a web app in Jetty as a target for unit-tested HTTP client components.

parameter.name: contextHandlers
parameter.description: List of other contexts to set up. Consider using instead the <jettyXml> element to specify external jetty xml config file. Optional.

parameter.name: contextXml
parameter.description: Location of a context xml configuration file whose contents will be applied to the webapp AFTER anything in <webApp>.Optional.

parameter.name: daemon
parameter.description: If true, the plugin should continue and not block. Otherwise the plugin will block further execution and you will need to use cntrl-c to stop it.

parameter.name: dumpOnStart
parameter.description: Use the dump() facility of jetty to print out the server configuration to logging

parameter.name: excludedGoals
parameter.description: List of goals that are NOT to be used

parameter.name: httpConnector
parameter.description: A ServerConnector to use.

parameter.name: jettyXml
parameter.description: Comma separated list of a jetty xml configuration files whose contents will be applied before any plugin configuration. Optional.

parameter.name: loginServices
parameter.description: List of security realms to set up. Consider using instead the <jettyXml> element to specify external jetty xml config file. Optional.

parameter.name: pluginArtifacts
parameter.description: The artifacts for the plugin itself.

parameter.name: project
parameter.description: The maven project.

parameter.name: projectArtifacts
parameter.description: The artifacts for the project.

parameter.name: reload
parameter.description:
reload can be set to either 'automatic' or 'manual'
if 'manual' then the context can be reloaded by a linefeed in the console if 'automatic' then traditional reloading on changed files is enabled.

parameter.name: requestLog
parameter.description: A RequestLog implementation to use for the webapp at runtime. Consider using instead the <jettyXml> element to specify external jetty xml config file. Optional.

parameter.name: scanIntervalSeconds
parameter.description: The interval in seconds to scan the webapp for changes and restart the context if necessary. Ignored if reload is enabled. Disabled by default.

parameter.name: server
parameter.description: A wrapper for the Server object

parameter.name: skip
parameter.description: Skip this mojo execution.

parameter.name: stopKey
parameter.description: Key to provide when stopping jetty on executing java -DSTOP.KEY=<stopKey> -DSTOP.PORT=<stopPort> -jar start.jar --stop

parameter.name: stopPort
parameter.description: Port to listen to stop jetty on executing -DSTOP.PORT=<stopPort> -DSTOP.KEY=<stopKey> -jar start.jar --stop

parameter.name: systemProperties
parameter.description: System properties to set before execution. Note that these properties will NOT override System properties that have been set on the command line or by the JVM. They WILL override System properties that have been set via systemPropertiesFile. Optional.

parameter.name: systemPropertiesFile
parameter.description:
File containing system properties to be set before execution
Note that these properties will NOT override System properties that have been set on the command line, by the JVM, or directly in the POM via systemProperties. Optional.

parameter.name: useProvidedScope
parameter.description: Whether or not to include dependencies on the plugin's classpath with <scope>provided</scope> Use WITH CAUTION as you may wind up with duplicate jars/classes.

parameter.name: war
parameter.description: The location of the war file.

parameter.name: webApp
parameter.description: An instance of org.eclipse.jetty.webapp.WebAppContext that represents the webapp. Use any of its setters to configure the webapp. This is the preferred and most flexible method of configuration, rather than using the (deprecated) individual parameters like "tmpDirectory", "contextPath" etc.

parameter.name: classesDirectory
parameter.description: The directory containing generated classes.

parameter.name: contextHandlers
parameter.description: List of other contexts to set up. Consider using instead the <jettyXml> element to specify external jetty xml config file. Optional.

parameter.name: contextXml
parameter.description: Location of a context xml configuration file whose contents will be applied to the webapp AFTER anything in <webApp>.Optional.

parameter.description: Use the dump() facility of jetty to print out the server configuration to logging

parameter.description: An optional pattern for includes/excludes of classes in the classesDirectory

parameter.description: List of files or directories to additionally periodically scan for changes. Optional.

parameter.name: systemPropertiesFile
parameter.description:
File containing system properties to be set before execution
Note that these properties will NOT override System properties that have been set on the command line, by the JVM, or directly in the POM via systemProperties. Optional.

parameter.name: target
parameter.description: The target directory

parameter.name: testClassesDirectory
parameter.description: The directory containing generated test classes.

parameter.name: useProvidedScope
parameter.description: Whether or not to include dependencies on the plugin's classpath with <scope>provided</scope> Use WITH CAUTION as you may wind up with duplicate jars/classes.

parameter.name: useTestScope
webApp
parameter.description: An instance of org.eclipse.jetty.webapp.WebAppContext that represents the webapp. Use any of its setters to configure the webapp. This is the preferred and most flexible method of configuration, rather than using the (deprecated) individual parameters like "tmpDirectory", "contextPath" etc.

parameter.name: webAppSourceDirectory
parameter.description: Root directory for all html/jsp etc files

parameter.name: webXml
parameter.description: The default location of the web.xml file. Will be used if <webApp><descriptor> is not set.

mojo.description:
Display help information on jetty-maven-plugin.
Call mvn jetty:help -Ddetail=true -Dgoal=<goal-name> to display parameter details.

parameter.name: detail
parameter.description: If true, display all settable properties for each goal.

parameter.name: goal
parameter.description: The name of the goal for which to show help. If unspecified, all goals will be displayed.

parameter.name: indentSize
parameter.description: The number of spaces per indentation level, should be positive.

parameter.name: lineLength
parameter.description: The maximum length of a display line, should be positive.

mojo.description:
This goal is used in-situ on a Maven project without first requiring that the project is assembled into a war, saving time during the development cycle.

The plugin forks a parallel lifecycle to ensure that the "compile" phase has been completed before invoking Jetty. This means that you do not need to explicity execute a "mvn compile" first. It also means that a "mvn clean jetty:run" will ensure that a full fresh compile is done before invoking Jetty.

Once invoked, the plugin can be configured to run continuously, scanning for changes in the project and automatically performing a hot redeploy when necessary. This allows the developer to concentrate on coding changes to the project using their IDE of choice and have those changes immediately and transparently reflected in the running web container, eliminating development time that is wasted on rebuilding, reassembling and redeploying.

You may also specify the location of a jetty.xml file whose contents will be applied before any plugin configuration. This can be used, for example, to deploy a static webapp that is not part of your maven build.

There is a reference guide to the configuration parameters for this plugin.

parameter.name: classesDirectory
parameter.description: The directory containing generated classes.

parameter.name: contextHandlers
parameter.description: List of other contexts to set up. Consider using instead the <jettyXml> element to specify external jetty xml config file. Optional.

parameter.name: contextXml
parameter.description: Location of a context xml configuration file whose contents will be applied to the webapp AFTER anything in <webApp>.Optional.

parameter.name: dumpOnStart
parameter.description: Use the dump() facility of jetty to print out the server configuration to logging

parameter.name: excludedGoals
parameter.description: List of goals that are NOT to be used

parameter.name: httpConnector
parameter.description: A ServerConnector to use.

parameter.name: jettyXml
parameter.description: Comma separated list of a jetty xml configuration files whose contents will be applied before any plugin configuration. Optional.

parameter.name: loginServices
parameter.description: List of security realms to set up. Consider using instead the <jettyXml> element to specify external jetty xml config file. Optional.

parameter.description: The artifacts for the plugin itself.

parameter.description: The maven project.

parameter.name: projectArtifacts
parameter.description: The artifacts for the project.

parameter.description:
reload can be set to either 'automatic' or 'manual'
if 'manual' then the context can be reloaded by a linefeed in the console if 'automatic' then traditional reloading on changed files is enabled.

parameter.name: requestLog
parameter.description: A RequestLog implementation to use for the webapp at runtime. Consider using instead the <jettyXml> element to specify external jetty xml config file. Optional.

parameter.name: scanClassesPattern
parameter.description: An optional pattern for includes/excludes of classes in the classesDirectory

parameter.name: scanIntervalSeconds
parameter.description: The interval in seconds to scan the webapp for changes and restart the context if necessary. Ignored if reload is enabled. Disabled by default.

parameter.name: scanTargetPatterns
scanTargets
parameter.description: List of files or directories to additionally periodically scan for changes. Optional.

parameter.name: scanTestClassesPattern
parameter.description: An optional pattern for includes/excludes of classes in the testClassesDirectory

mojo.description:
This goal is used to assemble your webapp into an exploded war and automatically deploy it to Jetty.

Once invoked, the plugin runs continuously, and can be configured to scan for changes in the pom.xml and to WEB-INF/web.xml, WEB-INF/classes or WEB-INF/lib and hot redeploy when a change is detected.

You may also specify the location of a jetty.xml file whose contents will be applied before any plugin configuration. This can be used, for example, to deploy a static webapp that is not part of your maven build.

parameter.name: contextHandlers
parameter.description: List of other contexts to set up. Consider using instead the <jettyXml> element to specify external jetty xml config file. Optional.

parameter.name: contextXml
parameter.description: Location of a context xml configuration file whose contents will be applied to the webapp AFTER anything in <webApp>.Optional.

parameter.name: dumpOnStart
parameter.description: Use the dump() facility of jetty to print out the server configuration to logging

parameter.name: excludedGoals
parameter.description: List of goals that are NOT to be used

parameter.name: httpConnector
parameter.description: A ServerConnector to use.

parameter.name: jettyXml
parameter.description: Comma separated list of a jetty xml configuration files whose contents will be applied before any plugin configuration. Optional.

parameter.name: loginServices
parameter.description: List of security realms to set up. Consider using instead the <jettyXml> element to specify external jetty xml config file. Optional.

parameter.name: pluginArtifacts
parameter.description: The artifacts for the plugin itself.

parameter.name: project
parameter.description: The maven project.

parameter.description: The artifacts for the project.

parameter.name: stopPort
parameter.description: Port to listen to stop jetty on executing -DSTOP.PORT=<stopPort> -DSTOP.KEY=<stopKey> -jar start.jar --stop

parameter.name: systemProperties
parameter.description: System properties to set before execution. Note that these properties will NOT override System properties that have been set on the command line or by the JVM. They WILL override System properties that have been set via systemPropertiesFile. Optional.

parameter.name: systemPropertiesFile
parameter.description:
File containing system properties to be set before execution
Note that these properties will NOT override System properties that have been set on the command line, by the JVM, or directly in the POM via systemProperties. Optional.

parameter.name: useProvidedScope
parameter.description: Whether or not to include dependencies on the plugin's classpath with <scope>provided</scope> Use WITH CAUTION as you may wind up with duplicate jars/classes.

parameter.name: war
parameter.description: The location of the war file.

parameter.name: webApp
parameter.description: An instance of org.eclipse.jetty.webapp.WebAppContext that represents the webapp. Use any of its setters to configure the webapp. This is the preferred and most flexible method of configuration, rather than using the (deprecated) individual parameters like "tmpDirectory", "contextPath" etc.

mojo.description:
This goal is used to deploy your unassembled webapp into a forked JVM.

You need to define a jetty.xml file to configure connectors etc. You can use the normal setters of o.e.j.webapp.WebAppContext on the webApp configuration element for this plugin. You may also need context xml file for any particularly complex webapp setup. about your webapp.

Unlike the other jetty goals, this does NOT support the scanIntervalSeconds parameter: the webapp will be deployed only once.

The stopKey, stopPort configuration elements can be used to control the stopping of the forked process. By default, this plugin will launch the forked jetty instance and wait for it to complete (in which case it acts much like the jetty:run goal, and you will need to Cntrl-C to stop). By setting the configuration element waitForChild to false, the plugin will terminate after having forked the jetty process. In this case you can use the jetty:stop goal to terminate the process.

See http://www.eclipse.org/jetty/documentation for more information on this and other jetty plugins.

parameter.name: classesDirectory
parameter.description: The directory containing generated classes.

parameter.name: contextHandlers
parameter.description: List of other contexts to set up. Consider using instead the <jettyXml> element to specify external jetty xml config file. Optional.

parameter.name: contextXml
parameter.description: Location of a context xml configuration file whose contents will be applied to the webapp AFTER anything in <webApp>.Optional.

parameter.name: dumpOnStart
parameter.description: Use the dump() facility of jetty to print out the server configuration to logging

parameter.name: env
parameter.description: Extra environment variables to be passed to the forked process

parameter.name: excludedGoals
parameter.description: List of goals that are NOT to be used

parameter.name: forkWebXml
parameter.description: The file into which to generate the quickstart web xml for the forked process to use

parameter.name: httpConnector
parameter.description: A ServerConnector to use.

parameter.name: jettyXml
parameter.description: Comma separated list of a jetty xml configuration files whose contents will be applied before any plugin configuration. Optional.

parameter.name: jvmArgs
parameter.description: Arbitrary jvm args to pass to the forked process

parameter.name: loginServices
parameter.description: List of security realms to set up. Consider using instead the <jettyXml> element to specify external jetty xml config file. Optional.

parameter.name: scanIntervalSeconds

mojo.description:
This goal is used to assemble your webapp into a war and automatically deploy it to Jetty.

Once invoked, the plugin runs continuously and can be configured to scan for changes in the project and to the war file and automatically perform a hot redeploy when necessary.

You may also specify the location of a jetty.xml file whose contents will be applied before any plugin configuration. This can be used, for example, to deploy a static webapp that is not part of your maven build.

mojo.description:
This goal is similar to the jetty:run goal, EXCEPT that it is designed to be bound to an execution inside your pom, rather than being run from the command line.

When using it, be careful to ensure that you bind it to a phase in which all necessary generated files and classes for the webapp will have been created. If you run it from the command line, then also ensure that all necessary generated files and classes for the webapp already exist.

parameter.name: classesDirectory
parameter.description: The directory containing generated classes.

parameter.name: webXml
parameter.description: The default location of the web.xml file. Will be used if <webApp><descriptor> is not set.

mojo.description: JettyStopMojo - stops a running instance of jetty. The ff are required: -DstopKey=someKey -DstopPort=somePort

parameter.name: stopKey
parameter.description: Key to provide when stopping jetty on executing java -DSTOP.KEY=<stopKey> -DSTOP.PORT=<stopPort> -jar start.jar --stop

parameter.name: stopPort
parameter.description: Port to listen to stop jetty on sending stop command

parameter.name: stopWait
parameter.description: Max time in seconds that the plugin will wait for confirmation that jetty has stopped.
